t: Proverbs 31
The Words of King Lemuel
The*p words of King Lemuel. An oracle that his mother taught him:
What*pn are you doing, my son? What are you doing, son of my womb? What*ld are you doing, son of my vows?
Do*ln not give your strength to women, your*ld ways to those who destroy kings.
It*ln is not for kings, O Lemuel, it*ld is not for kings to drink wine, or*ld for rulers to take strong drink,
lest*ln they drink and forget what has been decreed and*ld pervert the rights of all the afflicted.
Give*ln strong drink to the one who is perishing, and*ld wine to those in bitter distress;
let*ln them drink and forget their poverty and*ld remember their misery no more.
Open*ln your mouth for the mute, for*ld the rights of all who are destitute.
Open*ln your mouth, judge righteously, defend*ld the rights of the poor and needy.
The Woman Who Fears the Lord
An*pn excellent wife who can find? She*ld is far more precious than jewels.
The*ln heart of her husband trusts in her, and*ld he will have no lack of gain.
She*ln does him good, and not harm, all*ld the days of her life.
She*ln seeks wool and flax, and*ld works with willing hands.
She*ln is like the ships of the merchant; she*ld brings her food from afar.
She*ln rises while it is yet night and*ld provides food for her household and*ld portions for her maidens.
She*ln considers a field and buys it; with*ld the fruit of her hands she plants a vineyard.
She*ln dresses herself with strength and*ld makes her arms strong.
She*ln perceives that her merchandise is profitable. Her*ld lamp does not go out at night.
She*ln puts her hands to the distaff, and*ld her hands hold the spindle.
She*ln opens her hand to the poor and*ld reaches out her hands to the needy.
She*ln is not afraid of snow for her household, for*ld all her household are clothed in scarlet.
She*ln makes bed coverings for herself; her*ld clothing is fine linen and purple.
Her*ln husband is known in the gates when*ld he sits among the elders of the land.
She*ln makes linen garments and sells them; she*ld delivers sashes to the merchant.
Strength*ln and dignity are her clothing, and*ld she laughs at the time to come.
She*ln opens her mouth with wisdom, and*ld the teaching of kindness is on her tongue.
She*ln looks well to the ways of her household and*ld does not eat the bread of idleness.
Her*ln children rise up and call her blessed; her*ld husband also, and he praises her:
“Many*ln women have done excellently, but*ld you surpass them all.”
Charm*ln is deceitful, and beauty is vain, but*ld a woman who fears the Lord*s is to be praised.
Give*ln her of the fruit of her hands, and*ld let her works praise her in the gates.
